awd_titl_txt: A reference grammar and tonal documentation of Seenku, an endangered Mande language
awd_abstract_narration:
Over half of the world's estimated 7,000 languages are tonal, and most are spoken by small populations, threatened by globalization and changing socioeconomic landscapes. This project will advance scientific understanding of tone and tonal languages more generally. This project will answer some of the many questions remaining about tone by focusing on a language displaying exceptional tonal complexity.  The investigation of a language with four tones, a relatively uncommon cross-linguistic pattern, will better inform linguists about the upper bounds on the number of distinct tones and the types of grammatical information represented solely through tone. The project will provide new insights into many questions remaining about tone and phonological reduction, and on the behavior of a complex tonal system in morphology and syntax. The results will be disseminated via a reference grammar that includes and fully documents tone in its grammatical context, as well as by archived, annotated language data. Broader impacts include fostering international scientific cooperation and training undergraduate students in methods of language documentation and analysis. This contributes to the national interest by enabling soft diplomacy through scientific and technological training of international partners and by producing language scientists for the twenty-first century with expertise in cutting-edge techniques. This award is co-funded by the Office of International Science and Engineering. 

This project focuses on documenting the grammatical structure of Seenku, an endangered Mande language of Burkina Faso. Even in the African context, Seenku is exceptional for its tonal complexity, both in the number of contrasting pitch levels and the range of uses of tone in the grammar. Special attention is paid to documenting and analyzing the tone system using a variety of innovative methods. First, the research team will develop a novel computational tool ATLAS (Automated Tone Level Annotation System) to automate the tonal annotation of documentary materials. Tone can be notoriously difficult and time-consuming to transcribe, and the development of this tool will help other researchers and linguistic communities working on tonal languages. Second, tone will be studied through a culturally unique tradition in which Seenku words are encoded on the xylophone through their tone and rhythm. Mechanisms like this produce tones without the segmental and other features, which interact with surface tone realizations. This mechanism provides a rare window into speakers' subconscious knowledge of their language, addressing questions of cognitive representations of tone. The main products of this project include a comprehensive reference grammar, a trilingual Seenku-English-French dictionary, and an archive of audio and video recordings of various speech genres, with time-aligned transcriptions and translations. These products are of use to linguists, anthropologists, ethnomusicologists, and non-governmental organizations (NGOs).

por.por_cntn:
This project set out to document Seenku, an endangered Mande language spoken in the West African country of Burkina Faso by around 15,000 people. An alarming number of languages around the world are falling silent as speakers shift to more dominant languages, whether global languages like English or French or, in the case of Seenku, regional languages like Jula. All languages display unique characteristics and are worthy of documentation, but we chose Seenku due to the remarkable complexity of its tone system. Four distinct levels of pitch differentiate between words, and these pitches can also combine on single syllables to produce another ten contours. In addition to distinguishing between words (so-called “lexical tone”), tone also plays an important role in the grammar of Seenku, for instance in marking the plural or conjugating verbs, and the tones of individual words can change based on neighboring words and sentence structure. 

Our aim was to analyze and describe the grammatical structure of Seenku, with particular attention to tone, through the documentation of a wide variety of speech genres, including traditional stories, personal narratives, procedural texts documenting important traditions like making shea butter or weaving baskets, songs, and natural conversation. To better understand this fluent speech, we carried out targeted elicitation and translation of different grammatical structures. This work resulted in the publication of Seenku’s first comprehensive reference grammar, A Grammar of Seenku (2020). In addition, several journal articles analyzed theoretical aspects of the tone system and its interaction with different levels of grammatical structure. For instance, we found evidence that the four levels of tone are produced by two binary tone features (+/-high and +/-upper) and that grammatical meaning like ‘plural’ can be marked with just one of these features rather than an overt suffix, as in English -s, or even a full tone.

The project led to the unexpected discovery of a musical tradition intimately connected with the tone system: the Sambla talking balafon. In this tradition, the tone and rhythm of Seenku words can be transposed into musical notes on the balafon, a xylophone-like instrument, which can then be used to communicate with members of the audience, other musicians, or even the spirit world. Collaboration with international Sambla musician Mamadou Diabate allowed us to analyze the “grammar” of this musical surrogate language and to share it with audiences around the United States. We also twice taught a course at Dartmouth College teaching undergraduates how to play and understand this musical language while exploring the connections between language and music.

Finally, an outstanding question in linguistics is how children are able to learn such complex tone systems, especially when pitch plays such a large role in grammar. This grant trained a team of Sambla university students to collect and transcribe a yearlong corpus of babies and toddlers speaking Seenku in order to study the emergence of lexical and grammatical tone. African languages are highly under-represented in language acquisition literature, and this Seenku corpus will provide data to explore a range of questions in language acquisition for years to come.
